veto.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: if someone in authority vetoes something, they refuse to allow it to happen, especially something that other people or organizations have agreed
veto.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: President Bush vetoed the bill on July 6.
veto.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to refuse to accept a particular plan or suggestion
veto.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Jenny wanted to invite all her friends, but I quickly vetoed that idea.
veto.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a refusal to give official permission for something, or the right to refuse to give such permission
veto.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The Senate had a sufficient majority to override the presidential veto  (=not accept his refusal).
de Gaulle’s veto on the British application to join the EEC
The head teacher has the right of veto over management-board decisions.
Washington’s veto of Seoul’s nuclear ambitions
veto.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to officially refuse to allow something to happen, especially something other people have agreed
veto.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: An attempt to use £35 million to strengthen the bank’s capital was vetoed by bank regulators.
